bibl.title: Letter from Julian Zunzunegui [Lopez] to Philip Showalter Hench, October 18, 1940

div1.p: Lopez states that his father leased land from Ignacio Rojas and that he himself lived in the structure identified as Camp Lazear Building No. 1 by Moran. He describes some of the structural features as unusual for Cuban buildings and states that Building No. 2 was torn down in 1927.

div1.head: Letter from Julian Zunzunegui [Lopez] to Philip Showalter Hench, October 18, 1940
div1.opener:
Havana, Cuba, Oct. 18, 1940.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
c/o Mr. John J. Moran.
Dear Sir:-
div1.p:
Agreeable to your request, transmitted to me through Mr.
Moran, in connection with a wooden building on the “Finca San José”,
Marianao, formerly the property of Dr. Ignacio Rojas and his family,
I wish to make the following statements:

In March, 1907, my father leased the limekilns and lime-
stone quarry from Dr. Ignacio Rojas. Close by were two small build-
ings (wooden), the use and occupancy of which were included in the
lease. My father took up residence in one of the two buildings and
had a partition built in it, converting it into two rooms. Later on,
he built another small room against one end of it and a kitchen
against the rear of the building, running its entire length, a fraction
over six (6) meters. I lived in this house continuously from March
1907 until 1936. I got married in 1920, my wife and myself continuing
to live in the building referred to. My father died in 1935. All
three of my children were born in this building, which Mr. Moran calls
“Building No. 1”, presumably having known of the building when it was
constructed in 1900, when I was only seven years old. This building
is an unusual one for Cuba, in more than one particular. First: The
double board wall, with tongued and grooved lumber on the inside and
weather boarding on the outside. Second: The ceiling, which does not
extend all the way up, whereas, in the customary Cuban construction, it
would run all the way up, although, more than likely, it might not have
any ceiling at all. Third: It has a stovepipe hole in one corner,
rarely, if ever, to be found in wooden buildings in Cuba. Since I
first lived in the house, I have never seen a stove there, as we do
not use stoves for heating in Cuba, due to the fact that we rarely, if
ever, have cold weather. What Mr. Moran refers to as “Building No.
2” was partly toppled over during the 1926 cyclone and torn down about
a year later. I pointed out to Mr. Moran where it stood. The one in
which I lived, we had to reinforce and it managed to withstand the
effects of the cyclone. I do not know who lived in either of the
two buildings between October, 1901 and March, 1907.
div1.closer:
Yours very sincerely, Julian Zunzunegui Lopez I CERTIFY that this letter was
read by me to Sr. Zunzunegui,
translated into Spanish, before
he signed it:
Federico Oliveros.
